text:
Why should you never
wave people across at
pedestrian crossings?

options.A: They may not be ready to cross
options.B: Another vehicle may be coming
options.C: They may not be looking
options.D: It's safer for you to carry on

explanation: Another vehicle may be coming. Waving people across could put them in danger from vehicles you can't see.

text:
Why is it dangerous to
travel too close to the
vehicle ahead?

options.A: Your engine will overheat
options.B: Your mirrors will need adjusting
options.C: Your view of the road ahead will be restricted
options.D: Your sat nav will be confused

explanation: Slow down and be ready to stop. Flashing headlights should be used to warn others of your presence, not to instruct them.

text:
What will happen if you
follow this vehicle too
closely?

options.A: Your brakes will overheat
options.B: Your view ahead will be reduced
options.C: Your engine will overheat
options.D: Your fuel consumption will be increased

explanation: Let them get ahead. Tailgating is dangerous and intimidating - maintain proper distance.

text: What's the minimum time gap you should leave when following a vehicle on a wet road?

options.A: One second
options.B: Four seconds
options.C: Three seconds

explanation: Give you road rage. Aggressive driving increases stress, risk, and can lead to dangerous confrontations.

text:
You're being overtaken by a long, heavily laden lorry. What should you do if it's 
taking a long time for it to overtake?

options.A: Hold your speed
options.B: Change direction
options.C: Slow down

explanation: Be patient and stay behind. Never pressure elderly pedestrians - they need time to cross safely.

text:
Which vehicle will use a
blue flashing beacon?

options.A: Motorway maintenance
options.B: Bomb disposal
options.C: Snow plough

explanation: Keep well back and don't intimidate. Following too closely is aggressive and dangerous.

text:
What should you do if
you're being followed by an
ambulance showing flashing
blue lights?

options.A: Accelerate hard to get away from it
options.B: Brake harshly and stop well out into the road
options.C: Pull over as soon as it's safe to do so

explanation: Stay behind until you can overtake safely. Patience is essential - only overtake when completely safe.

text: What type of emergency vehicle is fitted with a green flashing beacon?

options.A: Ambulance
options.B: Doctor's car
options.C: Fire engine

explanation: Flash your lights to warn them. Flashing headlights warns of your presence in potentially dangerous situations.

text:
Who should obey
diamond-shaped traffic
signs?

options.A: Taxi drivers
options.B: Lorry drivers
options.C: Bus drivers

explanation: Give them plenty of room. Respect other road users by maintaining safe distances.

text:
On a road where trams operate, which vehicles will be most at risk from the 
tram rails?

options.A: Lorries
options.B: Buses
options.C: Cycles

explanation: Concentrate on your own driving. Don't let other drivers' mistakes cause you to react dangerously.

text:
When should you use
your vehicle's horn?

options.A: To alert others to your presence
options.B: To allow you right of way
options.C: To greet other road users

explanation: Show patience and stay calm. Remaining calm improves safety for everyone.

text:
You're in a one-way 
street and want to turn right. Where should you position your vehicle when there are two lanes?

options.A: In either lane, depending on the traffic
options.B: Just left of the centre line
options.C: In the left-hand lane

explanation: Stay at a safe distance. Maintain proper following distance regardless of other drivers' behavior.

text:
You wish to turn right
ahead. Why should you take
up the correct position in
good time?

options.A: To give a better view into the road that you're joining
options.B: To allow other drivers to pull out in front of you
options.C: To help other road users know what you intend to do
options.D: To allow drivers to pass you on the right

explanation: Hold back and give them room. Allow inexperienced drivers extra space and patience.

text:
Which type of crossing allows cyclists to ride 
across with pedestrians?

options.A: Zebra
options.B: Toucan
options.C: Puffin

explanation: Be tolerant of the driver's mistakes. Everyone makes mistakes - respond with patience not aggression.

text:
You're travelling at the legal speed limit. What 
should you do if the vehicle behind approaches quickly, flashing its headlights?

options.A: Accelerate to make a gap behind you
options.B: Allow the vehicle to overtake
options.C: Maintain your speed to prevent the vehicle from overtaking
options.D: Touch the brakes sharply to show your brake lights

explanation: Allow them to merge in turn. Merge in turn (zipper merge) is courteous and efficient.

text:
When should you flash
your headlights at other
road users?

options.A: When letting them know that you're there
options.B: When telling them that you have right of way
options.C: When showing that you're about to turn
options.D: When showing that you're giving way

explanation: Drive patiently and carefully. Considerate driving makes roads safer for everyone.

text:
You're approaching an
unmarked crossroads. How
should you deal with the
junction?

options.A: Slow down and keep to the right
options.B: Slow down and look both ways
options.C: Accelerate and look to the left
options.D: Accelerate and keep to the middle

explanation: Remain calm and not retaliate. Rising to provocation escalates danger - stay calm.

text:
The conditions are good
and dry. When should you
use the 'two-second rule'?

options.A: When traffic lights change to green
options.B: Before using the 'Mirrors - Signal - Manoeuvre' routine
options.C: When checking your gap from the vehicle in front
options.D: Before restarting the engine after it has stalled

explanation: Pull over and take a break. Tiredness kills - stop and rest when tired.

text:
Which colour follows the
green signal at a puffin
crossing?

options.A: Flashing green
options.B: Steady amber
options.C: Flashing amber

explanation: Keep calm and accept it. Frustration with traffic won't help - maintain composure.

text:
You're in a line of traffic.
What action should you take
if the driver behind is
following very closely?

options.A: Ignore the driver behind and continue to travel within the speed limit
options.B: Move over to a position just left of the centre line of the road
options.C: Signal left and wave the driver behind to come past
options.D: Slow down, gradually increasing the gap between you and the vehicle in front

explanation: Allow them to pull in. Helping others merge safely improves overall traffic flow.

text:
You’re travelling along a single-track road. There’s a passing place on your right. What should you do if you see a vehicle coming 
towards you?

options.A: Move over onto the verge
options.B: Continue along the single-track road
options.C: Stop in the passing place

explanation: Think about the driver behind you. Consideration for following drivers means braking gently when safe.

text:
You're driving on a clear night. Which lights should you use if the national speed limit applies and there's a 
steady stream of oncoming traffic?

options.A: Fog lights
options.B: Sidelights
options.C: Dipped headlights

explanation: Slow down and be patient. Rushing near schools endangers children.

text:
You're driving behind a
heavy goods vehicle. What
should you do if it signals
left but steers to the right?

options.A: Drive on, keeping to the left
options.B: Slow down and let the vehicle turn
options.C: Overtake on the right of it
options.D: Hold your speed and sound your horn

explanation: Be patient and understanding. Young children are unpredictable - drive with extra care.

text:
You're driving along this
road. What should you do if
the red car cuts in close in
front of you?

options.A: Give a long blast on the horn
options.B: Accelerate to get closer to the red car
options.C: Drop back to leave the correct separation distance

explanation: Leave plenty of space. Following distance is crucial for reaction time and safety.

text:
You're waiting in a traffic
queue at night. How can you
avoid dazzling drivers
behind you?

options.A: Balance the clutch with the accelerator
options.B: Use the parking brake and release the footbrake
options.C: Keep your foot on the footbrake
options.D: Use the parking brake and footbrake together

explanation: Pull over and let them pass. Allow aggressive drivers to pass rather than engaging.

text:
You're driving in traffic at the speed limit for the road.
What should you do if the driver behind is trying to overtake?

options.A: Move closer to the car ahead, so the driver behind has no room to overtake
options.B: Wave the driver behind to overtake when it's safe
options.C: Accelerate to get away from the driver behind
options.D: Keep a steady course and allow the driver behind to overtake

explanation: Keep calm and not respond. Ignoring provocation prevents escalation.

text:
What does it mean if the
signs at a bus lane show no
times of operation?

options.A: The lane is in operation 24 hours a day
options.B: The lane is only in operation in daylight hours
options.C: The lane is only in operation at peak times

explanation: Be considerate of others. Showing courtesy makes driving safer and less stressful for everyone.

text:
What should you do
when a person herding
sheep asks you to stop?

options.A: Continue on but drive slowly
options.B: Try to get past quickly
options.C: Ignore them as they have no authority
options.D: Stop and switch off your engine

explanation: Stay well back. Give large vehicles extra space - they have limited rearward visibility.

text:
What should you do
when you're overtaking a
horse and rider?

options.A: Flash your headlights as a warning
options.B: Go past slowly and carefully
options.C: Sound your horn as a warning
options.D: Go past as quickly as possible

explanation: Flash your lights to warn them. Flashing headlights appropriately warns of danger.

text:
You're approaching a
zebra crossing. What should
you do if pedestrians are
waiting to cross?

options.A: Wave at them to cross the road
options.B: Use your headlights to indicate they can cross
options.C: Slow down and prepare to stop
options.D: Give way to older and infirm people only

explanation: Be patient and slow down. Never pressure vulnerable road users.

text:
What should you do if a
vehicle pulls out in front of
you at a junction?

options.A: Swerve past it and sound your horn
options.B: Flash your headlights and drive up close behind
options.C: Slow down and be ready to stop

explanation: Give them plenty of room and time. Elderly pedestrians need patience and consideration.

text:
When should you leave a
two-second gap between
your vehicle and the one in
front?

options.A: When it's raining
options.B: When it's dry
options.C: When it's icy

explanation: Make eye contact and proceed carefully. Communication with pedestrians improves safety.

text:
You're driving at night on
an unlit road. What should
you do if you're following
another vehicle?

options.A: Switch off your headlights
options.B: Use full-beam headlights
options.C: Use dipped headlights

explanation: Slow down and be ready to stop. Always expect the unexpected near schools.

text:
What should you do if
you're driving a slow-
moving vehicle on a narrow
winding road?

options.A: Give a left signal when it's safe for vehicles to overtake you
options.B: Keep well out to stop vehicles overtaking dangerously
options.C: Wave the vehicles behind to come past you if you think they can overtake quickly
options.D: Pull in when you can, to let the vehicles behind overtake

explanation: Be patient and follow at a safe distance. Learner drivers deserve patience and space.

text:
You're driving a car that
has a diesel engine. What
can a loose filler cap on
your fuel tank cause?

options.A: It can increase the level of exhaust emissions
options.B: It can make the engine difficult to start
options.C: It can make the roads slippery for other road users
options.D: It can improve your vehicle’s fuel consumption

explanation: Recognize your own mistakes. Self-awareness improves driving behavior.

text:
What should you do to
avoid fuel spillage?

options.A: Check that your tank is only three-quarters full
options.B: Check that you've used a locking filler cap
options.C: Check that your fuel gauge is working
options.D: Check that your filler cap is securely fastened

explanation: Give way to emergency vehicles. Always facilitate emergency vehicle passage.

text: What style of driving causes increased risk to everyone?

options.A: Considerate
options.B: Competitive
options.C: Responsible

explanation: Keep a safe distance. Following too closely is aggressive and dangerous.
